question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Find the number of solutions to the equation
\[\frac{1}{(7 - x)(1 + x)(1 - x)} + \frac{3x^2 - 18x - 22}{(x^2 - 1)(x - 7)} + \frac{3}{x - 2} = \frac{3}{(x - 1)(x - 2)}.\]
inference: Final Answer: \\boxed{1}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
We can move the $\frac{3}{x - 2}$ to the right-hand side.  We can also combine the first two fractions, to get
\begin{align*}
\frac{3x^2 - 18x - 21}{(x - 1)(x + 1)(x - 7)} &= \frac{3}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} - \frac{3}{x - 2} \\
&= \frac{3 - 3(x - 1)}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} \\
&= \frac{6 - 3x}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} \\
&= \frac{3(2 - x)}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} \\
&= -\frac{3}{x - 1}.
\end{align*}Note that $3x^2 - 18x - 21$ factors as $3(x + 1)(x - 7),$ so
\[\frac{3(x + 1)(x - 7)}{(x - 1)(x + 1)(x - 7)} = -\frac{3}{x - 1}.\]This simplifies to
\[\frac{3}{x - 1} = -\frac{3}{x - 1}.\]This can never occur, so the number of solutions is $\boxed{0}.$
